summary: Ray Cline is mentioned in several documents related to intelligence matters during the 1960s, particularly in the context of the President's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board (PFIAB) meetings and CIA activities. He appears to have been involved in discussions regarding national reconnaissance programs, intelligence briefings, and the adaptation of intelligence to presidential needs, specifically during the transition from Kennedy to Johnson. Cline's involvement spans from the early 1960s through the mid-1960s, as evidenced by his presence in meeting minutes and discussions related to intelligence matters. The documents suggest he was a significant figure in the intelligence community, contributing to discussions on various global hotspots and intelligence programs.
significance: While Ray Cline is not directly linked to the JFK assassination in these documents, his presence in discussions involving Allen Dulles (who was a member of the Warren Commission) and his involvement in intelligence matters during the period surrounding the assassination suggest he was a key figure in the intelligence community at the time. His role in adapting intelligence briefings for President Johnson after Kennedy's assassination also highlights his significance in the transition period.
